title: Getting Started with partycoloR
text: partycoloR package extracts political party colors logos English Wikipedia party pages. useful political scientists data visualization practitioners want consistent, recognizable colors political parties charts graphs.

title: Getting Started with partycoloR
text: main function get_party_color() takes Wikipedia URLs returns party’s primary color hex code:
code: # Single party dem_url <- "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)" get_party_color(dem_url) #> "#0015BC"  # Multiple parties urls <- c(   "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)",   "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)",   "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Green_Party_of_the_United_States" ) get_party_color(urls) #> "#0015BC" "#E81B23" "#17AA5C"

title: Getting Started with partycoloR
text: parties one official color. Use all_colors = TRUE get colors:
code: # German CDU has black and orange cdu_url <- "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christian_Democratic_Union_of_Germany" get_party_color(cdu_url, all_colors = TRUE) #> [[1]] #> [1] "#000000" "#FF6600"

title: Getting Started with partycoloR
text: Use get_party_logo() get URL party’s logo image:
code: get_party_logo(dem_url) #> "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/..."

title: Getting Started with partycoloR
text: can download logos local file using download_party_logo(): Note file extension match actual image format. Many Wikipedia logos SVGs, check URL determine correct extension.
code: # Get logo URL and download it logo_url <- get_party_logo(dem_url) download_party_logo(logo_url, "democratic_logo.png")  # Or use a pipeline with get_party_logo_by_name() get_party_logo_by_name("SPD", country = "DEU") %>%   download_party_logo("spd_logo.svg")

title: Getting Started with partycoloR
text: efficiency, use get_party_info() extract color logo single request:
code: get_party_info(urls) #> # A tibble: 3 x 3 #>   url                                                      color   logo_url #>   <chr>                                                    <chr>   <chr> #> 1 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(Unite... #0015BC https://... #> 2 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_Party_(Unite... #E81B23 https://... #> 3 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Green_Party_of_the_Unit... #17AA5C https://...

title: Getting Started with partycoloR
text: functions designed work seamlessly dplyr::mutate():
code: parties <- tibble(   party = c("Democrats", "Republicans", "Greens"),   wiki_url = c(     "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)",     "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)",     "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Green_Party_of_the_United_States"   ) )  parties %>%   mutate(     color = get_party_color(wiki_url),     logo = get_party_logo(wiki_url)   )

title: Getting Started with partycoloR
text: using all_colors = TRUE, result list-column. Use purrr functions extract specific colors: Alternatively, unnest long format (one row per color):
code: library(purrr)  german_parties <- tibble(   party = c("CDU", "SPD"),   wiki_url = c(     "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christian_Democratic_Union_of_Germany",     "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_of_Germany"   ) )  # Extract all colors as a list-column, then extract individual colors german_parties %>%   mutate(     all_colors = get_party_color(wiki_url, all_colors = TRUE),     color_1 = map_chr(all_colors, pluck, 1, 1, .default = NA_character_),     color_2 = map_chr(all_colors, pluck, 1, 2, .default = NA_character_)   ) #> # A tibble: 2 x 5 #>   party wiki_url                              all_colors color_1 color_2 #>   <chr> <chr>                                 <list>     <chr>   <chr> #> 1 CDU   https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris.. <list [1]> #000000 #FF6600 #> 2 SPD   https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soci..  <list [1]> #E3000F NA german_parties %>%   mutate(all_colors = get_party_color(wiki_url, all_colors = TRUE)) %>%   tidyr::unnest_longer(all_colors) %>%   tidyr::unnest_longer(all_colors, values_to = "color") #> # A tibble: 3 x 3 #>   party wiki_url                                               color #>   <chr> <chr>                                                  <chr> #> 1 CDU   https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christian_Democratic...  #000000 #> 2 CDU   https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christian_Democratic...  #FF6600 #> 3 SPD   https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Democratic_Pa...  #E3000F

title: Getting Started with partycoloR
text: don’t Wikipedia URLs, can look parties name using Party Facts database integration.

title: Getting Started with partycoloR
code: # Download the current Party Facts Wikipedia dataset pf_data <- get_partyfacts_wikipedia() head(pf_data) #> # A tibble: 6 x 8 #>   country partyfacts_id url         name_short name  name_native year_founded #>   <chr>           <int> <chr>       <chr>      <chr> <chr>              <int> #> 1 AFG              6641 https://... NA         Afgh... NA                 1966 #> ...

title: Getting Started with partycoloR
code: # Search for a party by name lookup_party_url("SPD", country = "DEU") #> # A tibble: 1 x 8 #>   country partyfacts_id url                             name_short name #>   <chr>           <int> <chr>                           <chr>      <chr> #> 1 DEU              1375 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/... SPD      Social...  # Search across all countries lookup_party_url("Labour")

title: Getting Started with partycoloR
text: Use get_party_color_by_name() combine lookup color extraction:
code: # Get SPD color directly by name get_party_color_by_name("SPD", country = "DEU") #> "#E3000F"  # If multiple parties match, returns a tibble with all matches get_party_color_by_name("Labour") #> # A tibble: 12 x 9 #>    country partyfacts_id url    name_short name  ... color #>    ...

title: Getting Started with partycoloR
text: ’s use party colors ggplot2 visualization:
code: library(ggplot2)  # Example data: German 2021 election results german_parties <- tibble(   party = c("SPD", "CDU/CSU", "Greens", "FDP", "AfD", "Left"),   vote_share = c(25.7, 24.1, 14.8, 11.5, 10.3, 4.9),   wiki_url = c(     "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_of_Germany",     "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christian_Democratic_Union_of_Germany",     "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alliance_90/The_Greens",     "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_Democratic_Party_(Germany)",     "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alternative_for_Germany",     "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Left_(Germany)"   ) )  # Get party colors german_parties <- german_parties %>%   mutate(color = get_party_color(wiki_url))  # Create bar chart with party colors ggplot(german_parties, aes(x = reorder(party, -vote_share), y = vote_share)) +   geom_col(fill = german_parties$color) +   labs(     title = "German Federal Election 2021",     x = NULL,     y = "Vote Share (%)"   ) +   theme_minimal()

title: Getting Started with partycoloR
text: functions handle errors gracefully:
code: # Invalid URLs return NA get_party_color("https://not-wikipedia.com/page") #> NA  # Non-existent pages return NA get_party_color("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonexistent_Party_12345") #> NA  # Mixed valid and invalid URLs urls <- c(   "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)",   NA,   "invalid_url" ) get_party_color(urls) #> "#0015BC" NA NA

title: Getting Started with partycoloR
text: Starting version 0.3.0, partycoloR includes pre-scraped color logo data major political parties. means faster lookups without network requests: bundled data includes parties Party Facts Wikipedia dataset available color data. party bundled data, functions automatically fall back live Wikipedia scraping. use use_cache = FALSE: need current data (party recently changed colors) Working newly created party yet bundled dataset Wikipedia page recently updated new information
code: # By default, uses bundled data (instant lookup) get_party_color("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)")  # Force live scraping for most recent data get_party_color("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)",                 use_cache = FALSE)  # View the bundled dataset head(party_data)

title: Getting Started with partycoloR
text: Party Facts dataset also cached R session avoid repeated downloads:
code: # First call downloads the data pf_data <- get_partyfacts_wikipedia()  # Subsequent calls use the cache (faster) pf_data <- get_partyfacts_wikipedia()  # Clear the cache if needed clear_partycolor_cache()

title: Getting Started with partycoloR
text: Batch requests: processing many parties, pass URLs get_party_color() rather calling loop. Cache Party Facts data: ’ll multiple lookups, call get_partyfacts_wikipedia() pass result lookup_party_url(). Handle missing data: Always check NA values results, Wikipedia pages may color information may unexpected formatting. Wikipedia changes: scraping depends Wikipedia’s HTML structure. results seem wrong, Wikipedia page format may changed.

title: Getting Started with partycoloR
text: Party Facts - Party Facts links datasets political parties across wide range social science datasets ParlGov - Database parties, elections cabinets EU OECD democracies ParlGov Dashboard - R Shiny dashboard data ParlGov party colors partycoloR

what: Extract Party Colors and Logos from Wikipedia
title: Extract Party Colors and Logos from Wikipedia
text: Documentation: https://lwarode.github.io/partycoloR/ partycoloR extracts political party colors logos English Wikipedia party pages. Party colors play crucial role visually identifying political parties data visualizations research.

title: Extract Party Colors and Logos from Wikipedia
text: Fast lookups bundled party data Party Facts Wikipedia dataset (100x faster live scraping) Extract party colors (HEX codes) Wikipedia infoboxes Extract party logo URLs Handle parties multiple colors Integrate Party Facts database party lookups Works seamlessly dplyr/tidyverse workflows Automatic fallback live Wikipedia scraping parties bundled data

title: Extract Party Colors and Logos from Wikipedia
text: can install partycoloR GitHub:
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("lwarode/partycoloR")

title: Extract Party Colors and Logos from Wikipedia
code: library(partycoloR)  # Single party get_party_color("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)") #> "#0015BC"  # Multiple parties urls <- c(   "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)",   "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)" ) get_party_color(urls) #> "#0015BC" "#E81B23"

title: Extract Party Colors and Logos from Wikipedia
code: get_party_logo("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)") #> "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/..."  # Download a logo to file get_party_logo_by_name("SPD", country = "DEU") %>%   download_party_logo("spd_logo.svg")

title: Extract Party Colors and Logos from Wikipedia
code: get_party_info(urls) #> # A tibble: 2 x 3 #>   url                                                      color   logo_url #>   <chr>                                                    <chr>   <chr> #> 1 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(Unite... #0015BC https://... #> 2 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_Party_(Unite... #E81B23 https://...

title: Extract Party Colors and Logos from Wikipedia
code: library(dplyr)  parties <- tibble(   party = c("Democrats", "Republicans"),   wiki_url = urls )  parties %>%   mutate(color = get_party_color(wiki_url)) #> # A tibble: 2 x 3 #>   party       wiki_url                                               color #>   <chr>       <chr>                                                  <chr> #> 1 Democrats   https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(Un... #0015BC #> 2 Republicans https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_Party_(Un... #E81B23

title: Extract Party Colors and Logos from Wikipedia
text: Don’t Wikipedia URLs? Use Partyfacts integration:
code: # Download Partyfacts data pf_data <- get_partyfacts_wikipedia()  # Look up a party lookup_party_url("SPD", country = "DEU")  # Or get the color directly get_party_color_by_name("SPD", country = "DEU") #> "#E3000F"

title: Download party logo image — download_party_logo
text: Downloads party logo image URL saves file.

title: Download party logo image — download_party_logo
code: download_party_logo(logo_url, destfile, overwrite = FALSE)

title: Download party logo image — download_party_logo
text: logo_url character string logo URL ([get_party_logo()]). destfile Path image saved. overwrite Logical. `TRUE`, overwrite existing files.

title: Download party logo image — download_party_logo
text: Invisible `TRUE` successful, `FALSE` otherwise.

title: Download party logo image — download_party_logo
code: # \donttest{ if (curl::has_internet()) {   logo_url <- get_party_logo(     "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)"   )   tmp_file <- tempfile(fileext = ".png")   download_party_logo(logo_url, tmp_file)   unlink(tmp_file) } # }

what: Extract party color from Wikipedia — get_party_color
title: Extract party color from Wikipedia — get_party_color
text: Extracts primary party color (colors) political party's English Wikipedia page. function scrapes party infobox color information.

title: Extract party color from Wikipedia — get_party_color
code: get_party_color(url, all_colors = FALSE, normalize = TRUE, use_cache = TRUE)

title: Extract party color from Wikipedia — get_party_color
text: url character vector Wikipedia URLs political party pages. all_colors Logical. `FALSE` (default), returns first/primary color. `TRUE`, returns colors list. normalize Logical. `TRUE` (default), attempts normalize color values uppercase hex codes. Named colors (e.g., "red") converted hex codes. use_cache Logical. `TRUE` (default), looks data bundled `party_data` dataset first scraping Wikipedia. `FALSE`, always scrapes live Wikipedia. Using cache much faster reduces load Wikipedia servers.

title: Extract party color from Wikipedia — get_party_color
text: `all_colors = FALSE`, character vector hex color codes   (NA failed extractions). `all_colors = TRUE`, list   character vectors containing colors URL.

title: Extract party color from Wikipedia — get_party_color
text: default, function uses bundled `party_data` dataset contains pre-scraped data major political parties. provides instant lookups without network requests. party bundled data, function automatically falls back live Wikipedia scraping. Set `use_cache = FALSE` always scrape fresh data Wikipedia. function works scraping Wikipedia infobox (vcard table) spans background-color style attributes. depends Wikipedia's current HTML structure may occasionally fail page structure changes. use `dplyr::mutate()`, function vectorized `url` argument. URL processed independently.

title: Extract party color from Wikipedia — get_party_color
code: # \donttest{ if (curl::has_internet()) {   # Fast lookup using bundled data (default)   get_party_color("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)")    # Force live scraping for most recent data   get_party_color("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)",                   use_cache = FALSE)    # Multiple parties   urls <- c(     "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)",     "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)"   )   get_party_color(urls)    # Get all colors (some parties have multiple)   get_party_color(urls, all_colors = TRUE) } #> [[1]] #> [[1]][[1]] #> [1] "#3333FF" #>  #>  #> [[2]] #> [[2]][[1]] #> [1] "#E81B23" #>  #>  # }

what: Get party color by name — get_party_color_by_name
title: Get party color by name — get_party_color_by_name
text: convenience function combines party lookup color extraction. Searches party name, finds Wikipedia URL, extracts party color.

title: Get party color by name — get_party_color_by_name
code: get_party_color_by_name(   party_name,   country = NULL,   all_colors = FALSE,   data = NULL )

title: Get party color by name — get_party_color_by_name
text: party_name character string party name search . country Optional. ISO 3-letter country code filter results. all_colors Logical. `TRUE`, returns colors. Default `FALSE`. data Optional. Partyfacts dataset.

title: Get party color by name — get_party_color_by_name
text: exactly one party found, returns color(s). multiple   parties match, returns tibble party info colors. Returns NA   party found.

title: Get party color by name — get_party_color_by_name
code: # \donttest{ if (curl::has_internet()) {   # Get color for German SPD   get_party_color_by_name("SPD", country = "DEU")    # Search more broadly   get_party_color_by_name("Labour", country = "GBR") } #> # A tibble: 7 × 9 #>   country partyfacts_id url            name_short name  name_native year_founded #>   <chr>           <int> <chr>          <chr>      <chr> <chr>              <int> #> 1 GBR               234 https://en.wi… ILP        Inde… NA                  1893 #> 2 GBR              1516 https://en.wi… Lab        Labo… Labour Par…         1900 #> 3 GBR              2121 https://en.wi… NA         Nati… NA                  1918 #> 4 GBR              2122 https://en.wi… NLO        Nati… NA                  1931 #> 5 GBR              8757 https://en.wi… NILP       Nort… NA                  1924 #> 6 GBR               762 https://en.wi… SDLP       Soci… Páirtí Sói…         1970 #> 7 GBR              1277 https://en.wi… NA         Soci… NA                  1996 #> # ℹ 2 more variables: year_dissolved <int>, color <chr> # }

what: Extract party information from Wikipedia — get_party_info
title: Extract party information from Wikipedia — get_party_info
text: Extracts party color(s) logo URL political party's English Wikipedia page single call.

title: Extract party information from Wikipedia — get_party_info
code: get_party_info(url, all_colors = FALSE, use_cache = TRUE)

title: Extract party information from Wikipedia — get_party_info
text: url character vector Wikipedia URLs political party pages. all_colors Logical. `FALSE` (default), returns primary color `color` column. `TRUE`, adds `all_colors` list-column. use_cache Logical. `TRUE` (default), looks data bundled `party_data` dataset first scraping Wikipedia. `FALSE`, always scrapes live Wikipedia. Using cache much faster reduces load Wikipedia servers.

title: Extract party information from Wikipedia — get_party_info
text: tibble columns: `url`, `color` (primary color hex),   `logo_url`, optionally `all_colors` (list colors).

title: Extract party information from Wikipedia — get_party_info
text: default, function uses bundled `party_data` dataset contains pre-scraped data major political parties. provides instant lookups without network requests. party bundled data, function automatically falls back live Wikipedia scraping. Set `use_cache = FALSE` always scrape fresh data Wikipedia. function combines [get_party_color()] [get_party_logo()] single call, efficient need pieces information fetches Wikipedia page .

title: Extract party information from Wikipedia — get_party_info
code: # \donttest{ if (curl::has_internet()) {   # Fast lookup using bundled data (default)   urls <- c(     "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)",     "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)",     "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_of_Germany"   )   get_party_info(urls)    # Force live scraping for most recent data   get_party_info(urls, use_cache = FALSE)    # Include all colors   get_party_info(urls, all_colors = TRUE) } #> # A tibble: 3 × 4 #>   url                                                  color logo_url all_colors #>   <chr>                                                <chr> <chr>    <list>     #> 1 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(Uni… #333… https:/… <chr [1]>  #> 2 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_Party_(Uni… #E81… https:/… <chr [1]>  #> 3 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Democratic_Par… #E30… https:/… <chr [1]>  # }

code: get_party_info_by_name(   party_name,   country = NULL,   all_colors = FALSE,   data = NULL )

title: Get party info by name — get_party_info_by_name

title: Get party info by name — get_party_info_by_name
code: # \donttest{ if (curl::has_internet()) {   # Get info for German SPD   get_party_info_by_name("SPD", country = "DEU")    # Search more broadly with all colors   get_party_info_by_name("Labour", country = "GBR", all_colors = TRUE) } #> # A tibble: 7 × 11 #>   country partyfacts_id url            name_short name  name_native year_founded #>   <chr>           <int> <chr>          <chr>      <chr> <chr>              <int> #> 1 GBR               234 https://en.wi… ILP        Inde… NA                  1893 #> 2 GBR              1516 https://en.wi… Lab        Labo… Labour Par…         1900 #> 3 GBR              2121 https://en.wi… NA         Nati… NA                  1918 #> 4 GBR              2122 https://en.wi… NLO        Nati… NA                  1931 #> 5 GBR              8757 https://en.wi… NILP       Nort… NA                  1924 #> 6 GBR               762 https://en.wi… SDLP       Soci… Páirtí Sói…         1970 #> 7 GBR              1277 https://en.wi… NA         Soci… NA                  1996 #> # ℹ 4 more variables: year_dissolved <int>, color <chr>, logo_url <chr>, #> #   all_colors <list> # }

what: Extract party logo URL from Wikipedia — get_party_logo
title: Extract party logo URL from Wikipedia — get_party_logo
text: Extracts party logo image URL political party's English Wikipedia page. function scrapes party infobox logo image.

title: Extract party logo URL from Wikipedia — get_party_logo
code: get_party_logo(url, use_cache = TRUE)

title: Extract party logo URL from Wikipedia — get_party_logo
text: url character vector Wikipedia URLs political party pages. use_cache Logical. `TRUE` (default), looks data bundled `party_data` dataset first scraping Wikipedia. `FALSE`, always scrapes live Wikipedia. Using cache much faster reduces load Wikipedia servers.

title: Extract party logo URL from Wikipedia — get_party_logo
text: character vector logo image URLs (NA failed extractions   pages without logos).

title: Extract party logo URL from Wikipedia — get_party_logo
text: default, function uses bundled `party_data` dataset contains pre-scraped logo URLs major political parties. provides instant lookups without network requests. party bundled data, function automatically falls back live Wikipedia scraping. Set `use_cache = FALSE` always scrape fresh data Wikipedia. function looks logo images Wikipedia infobox. returned URL typically Wikimedia Commons thumbnail URL. Note party pages may logos, logo may non-standard location. returned URLs point image files hosted Wikimedia servers. can used directly R graphics downloaded processing. use `dplyr::mutate()`, function vectorized `url` argument.

title: Extract party logo URL from Wikipedia — get_party_logo
code: # \donttest{ if (curl::has_internet()) {   # Fast lookup using bundled data (default)   get_party_logo("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)")    # Force live scraping for most recent data   get_party_logo("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)",                  use_cache = FALSE)    # Multiple parties   urls <- c(     "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)",     "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)"   )   get_party_logo(urls) } #> [1] "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/US_Democratic_Party_2025_logo_%28positive%29.svg/330px-US_Democratic_Party_2025_logo_%28positive%29.svg.png" #> [2] "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/GOP_logo_%28positive%29.svg/250px-GOP_logo_%28positive%29.svg.png"                                           # }

title: Download Partyfacts Wikipedia data — get_partyfacts_wikipedia
text: Downloads current Partyfacts Wikipedia dataset containing party names, countries, Wikipedia URLs thousands political parties worldwide.

title: Download Partyfacts Wikipedia data — get_partyfacts_wikipedia
code: get_partyfacts_wikipedia(cache = TRUE)

title: Download Partyfacts Wikipedia data — get_partyfacts_wikipedia
text: cache Logical. `TRUE` (default), caches downloaded data current R session avoid repeated downloads.

title: Download Partyfacts Wikipedia data — get_partyfacts_wikipedia
text: tibble columns: country, partyfacts_id, url, name_short, name,   name_native, year_founded, year_dissolved.

title: Download Partyfacts Wikipedia data — get_partyfacts_wikipedia
text: data comes Partyfacts project (<https://partyfacts.herokuapp.com/>), links party datasets provides Wikipedia URLs political parties. data downloaded Partyfacts GitHub repository.

title: Download Partyfacts Wikipedia data — get_partyfacts_wikipedia
code: # \donttest{ if (curl::has_internet()) {   # Download the dataset   pf_data <- get_partyfacts_wikipedia()    # View parties from Germany   pf_data[pf_data$country == "DEU", ] } #> # A tibble: 60 × 8 #>    country partyfacts_id url           name_short name  name_native year_founded #>    <chr>           <int> <chr>         <chr>      <chr> <chr>              <int> #>  1 DEU              1976 https://en.w… AfD        Alte… Alternativ…         2013 #>  2 DEU              2068 https://en.w… NA         Bava… NA                  1895 #>  3 DEU              1825 https://en.w… NA         Bava… Bayerische…         1918 #>  4 DEU                61 https://en.w… BP         Bava… Bayernpart…         1946 #>  5 DEU              1816 https://en.w… GRÜNE      Alli… Bündnis 90…         1993 #>  6 DEU               865 https://en.w… GRÜNE      Alli… Bündnis 90…         1993 #>  7 DEU              1375 https://en.w… CDU        Chri… Christlich…         1945 #>  8 DEU               211 https://en.w… CDU/CSU    CDU/… NA                  1949 #>  9 DEU              1831 https://en.w… NA         Chri… NA                  1928 #> 10 DEU              8723 https://en.w… NA         Chri… Christlich…         1878 #> # ℹ 50 more rows #> # ℹ 1 more variable: year_dissolved <int> # }

what: Look up party Wikipedia URL — lookup_party_url
title: Look up party Wikipedia URL — lookup_party_url
text: Search Partyfacts Wikipedia dataset party name /country.

title: Look up party Wikipedia URL — lookup_party_url
code: lookup_party_url(party_name, country = NULL, data = NULL, exact = FALSE)

title: Look up party Wikipedia URL — lookup_party_url
text: party_name character string search party names. search case-insensitive matches partial names. country Optional. ISO 3-letter country code (e.g., "DEU", "USA", "GBR") filter results. data Optional. Partyfacts dataset ([get_partyfacts_wikipedia()]). provided, downloads data automatically. exact Logical. `TRUE`, requires exact match party name. Default `FALSE` (partial matching).

title: Look up party Wikipedia URL — lookup_party_url
text: tibble matching parties Wikipedia URLs.

title: Look up party Wikipedia URL — lookup_party_url
code: # \donttest{ if (curl::has_internet()) {   # Search for parties with "Democratic" in the name   lookup_party_url("Democratic")    # Search within a specific country   lookup_party_url("SPD", country = "DEU")    # Exact match   lookup_party_url("CDU", country = "DEU", exact = TRUE) } #> # A tibble: 1 × 8 #>   country partyfacts_id url            name_short name  name_native year_founded #>   <chr>           <int> <chr>          <chr>      <chr> <chr>              <int> #> 1 DEU              1375 https://en.wi… CDU        Chri… Christlich…         1945 #> # ℹ 1 more variable: year_dissolved <int> # }

what: Bundled party colors and logos dataset — party_data
title: Bundled party colors and logos dataset — party_data
text: dataset containing pre-scraped party colors logos Wikipedia political parties Party Facts database. dataset bundled package provide fast lookups without requiring live Wikipedia scraping.

title: Bundled party colors and logos dataset — party_data
code: party_data

title: Bundled party colors and logos dataset — party_data
text: tibble 5 columns: url Wikipedia URL party page (character) color Primary party color normalized HEX code, e.g., "#0015BC" (character) all_colors List column containing party colors character vector (list) logo_url URL party logo image Wikimedia Commons (character) last_updated Date data scraped Wikipedia (Date)

title: Bundled party colors and logos dataset — party_data
text: Data scraped English Wikipedia party pages. Party list Party Facts database: Döring Regel (2019) <doi:10.1177/1354068818820671> Bederke, Döring, Regel (2023) <doi:10.7910/DVN/TJINLQ>.

title: Bundled party colors and logos dataset — party_data
text: dataset contains pre-scraped color logo information political parties Party Facts Wikipedia dataset, covering parties worldwide English Wikipedia pages available color data. data used default [get_party_color()], [get_party_logo()], [get_party_info()] provide instant lookups. party found dataset, functions automatically fall back live Wikipedia scraping. Color codes normalized uppercase 6-digit HEX format (e.g., "#FF0000"). Logo URLs point images hosted Wikimedia Commons. regenerate update dataset, see script `data-raw/update.R` package source.

what: partycoloR: Extract Party Colors and Logos from Wikipedia — partycoloR-package
title: partycoloR: Extract Party Colors and Logos from Wikipedia — partycoloR-package
text: Extract political party colors logos English Wikipedia party pages. Provides functions scrape party infoboxes color codes (HEX HTML color names) logo images. Includes integration Party Facts database easy party lookups. Designed political scientists party researchers working electoral party data. Party Facts, see Döring Regel (2019) doi:10.1177/1354068818820671  Bederke, Döring, Regel (2023) doi:10.7910/DVN/TJINLQ .

title: partycoloR: Extract Party Colors and Logos from Wikipedia — partycoloR-package
text: Maintainer: Lukas Warode lukas.warode@gmx.de

what: Extract party colors from Wikipedia (legacy function) — wikipedia_party_color
title: Extract party colors from Wikipedia (legacy function) — wikipedia_party_color
text: `r lifecycle::badge("deprecated")` function deprecated. Please use [get_party_color()] instead.

title: Extract party colors from Wikipedia (legacy function) — wikipedia_party_color
code: wikipedia_party_color(party_url_list)

title: Extract party colors from Wikipedia (legacy function) — wikipedia_party_color
text: party_url_list list Wikipedia political party URLs

title: Extract party colors from Wikipedia (legacy function) — wikipedia_party_color
text: data frame / tibble containing extracted color codes Wikipedia

title: Extract party colors from Wikipedia (legacy function) — wikipedia_party_color
code: # \donttest{ if (curl::has_internet()) {   party_list <- c(     "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)",     "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)"   )   wikipedia_party_color(party_list) } #> Warning: 'wikipedia_party_color' is deprecated. #> Use 'get_party_color' instead. #> See help("Deprecated") #> # A tibble: 2 × 2 #>   url                                                            color_1 #>   <chr>                                                          <chr>   #> 1 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States) #3333FF #> 2 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States) #E81B23 # }

title: partycoloR 0.3.0
text: Bundled party data: Package now includes pre-scraped color logo data Party Facts Wikipedia dataset, providing instant lookups without Wikipedia scraping. dramatically improves performance reduces load Wikipedia servers. New dataset party_data - bundled party colors logos Wikipedia columns: url, color, all_colors, logo_url, last_updated. Includes parties Party Facts Wikipedia dataset available color data. New parameter use_cache (default TRUE) get_party_color(), get_party_logo(), get_party_info() prefer bundled data live scraping. Set FALSE always scrape fresh data Wikipedia. New script data-raw/update.R regenerate bundled data Wikipedia. Package maintainers can use periodically update cached data.

title: partycoloR 0.3.0
text: Faster performance: Bundled data lookups ~100x faster live scraping parties cache. Reduced Wikipedia server load: Default behavior now uses cached data, graceful fallback live scraping parties bundled dataset. Graceful fallback: party bundled data, functions automatically fall back live scraping, ensuring full backward compatibility. Offline capability: Cached parties can accessed without internet connection.

title: partycoloR 0.3.0
text: Added comprehensive documentation party_data dataset. Updated function examples demonstrate cached live scraping modes. Added new test suite test-bundled_data.R 20+ tests cache functionality. Updated vignette section bundled data vs. live scraping.

title: partycoloR 0.3.0
text: Added LazyData: true DESCRIPTION efficient data loading. Added cache lookup helper functions: lookup_cached_color(), lookup_cached_logo(), lookup_cached_info(). Updated integration tests explicitly use use_cache = FALSE testing live scraping functionality.

title: partycoloR 0.2.0
text: CRAN release: 2026-01-27

title: partycoloR 0.2.0
text: New function get_party_color() - vectorized color extraction support multiple colors (all_colors parameter) color normalization. New function get_party_logo() - extract party logo URLs Wikipedia pages. New function get_party_info() - extract color logo single call better efficiency. New Partyfacts integration: get_partyfacts_wikipedia() - download Partyfacts Wikipedia dataset lookup_party_url() - search parties name country get_party_color_by_name() - convenience function combining lookup color extraction clear_partycolor_cache() - clear cached Partyfacts data

title: partycoloR 0.2.0
text: Functions now fully vectorized work seamlessly dplyr::mutate(). Better error handling - invalid URLs return NA instead throwing errors. Color normalization converts named colors (e.g., “red”) hex codes expands 3-digit hex codes 6 digits. Added comprehensive test suite using testthat. Complete vignette examples best practices. Updated use modern tidyverse patterns (replaced gather/spread pivot_longer/pivot_wider).

title: partycoloR 0.2.0
text: original wikipedia_party_color() function now deprecated. Use get_party_color() instead. package now requires R >= 4.1.0.

title: partycoloR 0.2.0
text: Added detailed function documentation examples. New vignette: “Getting Started partycoloR”. Updated README feature overview quick start guide.

title: partycoloR 0.1.0
text: Initial release wikipedia_party_color() function. Extract party colors English Wikipedia party pages.
